name: Jam Ring keychain
description:
Carry a bit of almost edible history around with you daily! These hand moulded keychains are are often mistaken for the real thing and have a great story behind them. Now you just need to choose your favourite British biscuit!

Each keychain is made from oven clay. Biscuit ‘dough’ is made using a selection of carefully blended colours to achieve that perfect biscuit colour. Once this is well kneaded to make sure its soft, each biscuit part is individually hand moulded. Arguably the most exciting part, the biscuit parts are then baked in the oven like the real thing. Once cool, jam rings have their gooey jam heart painted and the keychains are put together and carefully packaged for your enjoyment!

The story
I have a sweet tooth. I admit it. Now I can justify it, my mum decided that young Candida was to only eat sweet things and sweets at the weekend. Weeks were very long for me, weekends were far too short (sound familiar?) and thus young candida grew into an adult sugar fiend. Cakes, sweets, chocolate, you name it, I love it! But biscuits were always a very special treat for me when I was young. The memory of looking at that plate of four (that was a precise number determined at some point by my mum) bourbons, custard creams or sometimes a surprise appearance (chocolate disgestive, choc chip cookies, to name a few) always makes me think of how I would smile and just be so exstaticly happy, savoring each one. Therefore, it comes as no surprise that while looking for a bit of new inspiration with my usual biscuit and cuppa, I got to wondering ‘so whats the story behind these special bourbons?’ and the Biscuit Town range was born:


A little research into the Bourbon opened a whole world of biscuit greatness that I couldn’t have predicted. The bourbon was invented in 1910 by ‘Peek Freans’, a biscuit factory which turned out to be MY LOCAL factory!  Peek Freans employed generations of Bermondsey residents for over 120 years. The area became know as “Biscuit Town’ and when speaking to local residents they recalled the smell of biscuits which filled the air! Suddenly I discovered that many friends and local residents had a grandma or uncle that had worked in the factory. Inspired by the memories and stories I had heard, I created the ‘Biscuit Town’ range to commemorate those who worked for the factory and to to get these Iconic biscuits full of childhood memories back into our daily lives.

name: Jam ring Jotter
description:
Jam Ring Book
A hand-printed A7 book (approx. 105 x 74 mm/4.1 x. 2.9 in) with lined (light raspberry dots to be exact) pages, hand bound with raspberry satin ribbon.

I love these note books to jot down my daily ideas, thoughts, quotes, lists, things I need to look up, recipes and more! Best of all they are the perfect size to slip into your back pocket or purse, so they are always there when you want to scribble a note.

Customers also use them for their art or fashion sketches( see the Bourbon, Pink Wafer & Party Ring jotters). The light ivory 100gsm paper is perfect for this as the page colour is inviting, not stark, and the weight of the paper means that the notebooks are suitable for pencil, charcoal, pastel or ink. They are versatile little things. 

As you will find out whilst looking around my store, there is a story behind each of my products, and this little jotter is no exception. 

The story
I have a sweet tooth. I admit it. Now I can justify it, my mum decided that young Candida was to only eat sweet things and sweets at the weekend. Weeks were very long for me, weekends were far too short (sound familiar?) and thus young candida grew into an adult sugar fiend. Cakes, sweets, chocolate, you name it, I love it! But biscuits were always a very special treat for me when I was young. The memory of looking at that plate of four (that was a precise number determined at some point by my mum) bourbons, custard creams or sometimes a surprise appearance (chocolate disgestive, choc chip cookies, to name a few) always makes me think of how I would smile and just be so exstaticly happy, savoring each one. Therefore, it comes as no surprise that while looking for a bit of new inspiration with my usual biscuit and cuppa, I got to wondering ‘so whats the story behind these special bourbons?’ and the Biscuit Town range was born:

A little research into the Bourbon opened a whole world of biscuit greatness that I couldn’t have predicted. The bourbon was invented in 1910 by ‘Peek Freans’, a biscuit factory which turned out to be MY LOCAL factory!  Peek Freans employed generations of Bermondsey residents for over 120 years. The area became know as “Biscuit Town’ and when speaking to local residents they recalled the smell of biscuits which filled the air! Suddenly I discovered that many friends and local residents had a grandma or uncle that had worked in the factory. Inspired by the memories and stories I had heard, I created the ‘Biscuit Town’ range to commemorate those who worked for the factory and to to get these Iconic biscuits full of childhood memories back into our daily lives. 

The making process
I made my own rubber stamps for each biscuit within the range, carefully carving the iconic shapes of each biscuit (yes the Custard Cream was painfully time consuming, it’s got more curls than you think!)

Once I had my stamps, I made numerous trips to craft shops with one confusing question-”So I want to find an ink pad in a jam ring colour-can you help me?” Determined to replicate the golden bake on these little biscuits, I tried and tested many colours, mixes and types of ink pad until I was happy that they looked like the biscuits I remember so excitedly from when I was  keen biscuit eating child.

Choosing a thicker paper weight for the cover of the book, I set about hand printing the biscuits. I chose the ivory paper for the inside pages to complement the covers and bound the books using a pamphlet stitch with a satin ribbon to complement the raspberry heart of the beloved jam ring. Finally the book was trimmed down and the corners of the books were rounded. (theres something exciting about rounded corners is there not?)
